Method Detail

getInstance

public static Appboy getInstance(android.content.Context context)
Static method that returns the Appboy singleton. All requests to Appboy are made through this instance.

Parameters:
context - Current context
Returns:
the singleton Appboy instance

openSession

public boolean openSession(android.app.Activity activity)
Description copied from interface: IAppboy
Opens a new session or resumes the previous session. A call to IAppboy.openSession(Activity) within 10 seconds of a call to IAppboy.closeSession(Activity) will cause the previous session to be resumed. This is done so that transitions from one Activity to another does not create a new session each time. This must be called in every Activity's onStart method.

Specified by:
openSession in interface IAppboy
Parameters:
activity - The current Activity.
Returns:
a boolean with the value of TRUE is a new session was created or FALSE is an existing session was resumed.
See Also:
IAppboy.openSession(android.app.Activity)

closeSession

public boolean closeSession(android.app.Activity activity)
Description copied from interface: IAppboy
Closes the current session. The session may be reopened if a call is made to IAppboy.openSession(Activity) within 10 seconds. This must be called every the Activity's onStop method. Note: Android does not guarantee a total ordering of lifecycle methods, so in the event that the onStart() and onStop() lifecycle methods get called out of order, we treat the call to closeSession(Activity) as a no-op and return false.

Specified by:
closeSession in interface IAppboy
Parameters:
activity - The current Activity.
Returns:
a boolean indicating whether or not Appboy needs to attempt to close the session.
See Also:
IAppboy.closeSession(android.app.Activity)

submitFeedback

public boolean submitFeedback(java.lang.String replyToEmail,
                              java.lang.String message,
                              boolean isReportingABug)
Description copied from interface: IAppboy
Submits a piece of feedback to the Appboy feedback center so that it can be handled in the Appboy dashboard. The request to submit feedback is made immediately, however, this method does not block and will return as soon as the feedback request is placed on the network queue. Feedback submissions will also flush the session/events queue when the network request is actually made.

Specified by:
submitFeedback in interface IAppboy
Parameters:
replyToEmail - The email address to send feedback replies to.
message - The message input by the user. Must be non-null and non-empty.
isReportingABug - Flag indicating whether or not the feedback describes a bug, or is merely a suggestion/question.
Returns:
a boolean indicating whether or not the feedback item was successfully queued for delivery.
See Also:
IAppboy.submitFeedback(String, String, boolean)

logCustomEvent

public boolean logCustomEvent(java.lang.String eventName)
Description copied from interface: IAppboy
Reports a custom named event.

Specified by:
logCustomEvent in interface IAppboy
Parameters:
eventName - The String identifier for the event to track. Best practice is to track generic events useful for segmenting, instead of specific user actions (i.e. track watched_sports_video instead of watched_video_adrian_peterson_td_mnf).
Returns:
a boolean indicating whether or not the event was successfully attached to the session (to be flushed later).
See Also:
IAppboy.logCustomEvent(String)

logPurchase

public boolean logPurchase(java.lang.String productId,
                           int priceInCents)
Description copied from interface: IAppboy
Reports that the current user made an in app purchase. Useful for tracking and segmenting users more likely to make purchases.

Specified by:
logPurchase in interface IAppboy
Parameters:
productId - The String identifier for the product purchased. Usually the Google Play SKU.
priceInCents - The price paid. All calls to logPurchase should be normalized to a single currency for consistency in filtering across a user base.
Returns:
a boolean indicating whether or not the event was successfully attached to the session (to be flushed later).
See Also:
IAppboy.logPurchase(String, int)

logShare in interface IAppboy
Parameters:

logFeedCardImpression

public boolean logFeedCardImpression(java.lang.String cardId)
Description copied from interface: IAppboy
Reports a feed card was displayed to the user. Card impressions tracks how many times a card has been seen. Impressions should only be reported once the card becomes viewable to the user. Cards that are part of the stream but not visible should not log a card impression. If a card is viewed more than once in a particular view, it generates only one impression. If closed an reopened, a card will again generate an impression. 

Specified by:
logFeedCardImpression in interface IAppboy
Parameters:
cardId - The ID of the feed card.
See Also:
IAppboy.logFeedCardImpression(String)

requestFeedRefreshFromCache

public void requestFeedRefreshFromCache()
Description copied from interface: IAppboy
Requests a refresh of the news feed from offline storage. The result of this call will be reported asynchronously via a FeedUpdatedEvent, similar to a call to IAppboy.requestFeedRefresh().

Specified by:
requestFeedRefreshFromCache in interface IAppboy
See Also:
IAppboy.requestFeedRefreshFromCache()

requestFeedRefresh

public void requestFeedRefresh()
Description copied from interface: IAppboy
Requests an immediate refresh of the news feed from the Appboy server. All refresh requests also flush the session/events queue when the network request executes. Results of refresh calls are reported asynchronously via events. Events can be subscribed to with other methods in this class. If the network call returns before any subscribers are active, the result will be lost.

Specified by:
requestFeedRefresh in interface IAppboy

requestSlideupRefresh

public void requestSlideupRefresh()
Description copied from interface: IAppboy
Requests an immediate refresh of only the slideup. Use this if you want to check for new slideup messages, but don't want to incur the overhead of pulling down an entire new message feed. All refresh requests also flush the session/events queue when the network request is actually made. Results of refresh calls are reported asynchronously via events. Events can be subscribed to with other methods in this class. If the network call returns before any subscribers are active, the result will be lost.

Specified by:
requestSlideupRefresh in interface IAppboy
See Also:
IAppboy.requestSlideupRefresh()

subscribeToNewSlideups

public void subscribeToNewSlideups(IEventSubscriber<SlideupEvent> subscriber)
Description copied from interface: IAppboy
Subscribes to a news Slideup event. The subscriber callback will be called when the a new slideup is sent. The subscriber will be called with a SlideupEvent. Subscriptions should be cleaned up manually by calling IAppboy.removeSingleSubscription(com.appboy.events.IEventSubscriber, Class). All events are triggered from background threads and isolate any encountered exceptions. If you need to do work on the UI thread in response to an event, you will need to coordinate that in the IEventSubscriber's trigger method.

Specified by:
subscribeToNewSlideups in interface IAppboy
Parameters:
subscriber - A callback that should be executed when the news feed is updated.
See Also:
IAppboy.subscribeToNewSlideups(com.appboy.events.IEventSubscriber)

public void subscribeToFeedUpdates(IEventSubscriber<FeedUpdatedEvent> subscriber)
Description copied from interface: IAppboy
Subscribes to a news feed event. The subscriber callback will be called when the news feed is updated. The subscriber will be called with a FeedUpdatedEvent. Subscriptions should be cleaned up manually by calling IAppboy.removeSingleSubscription(com.appboy.events.IEventSubscriber, Class). All events are triggered from background threads and isolate any encountered exceptions. If you need to do work on the UI thread in response to an event, you will need to coordinate that in the IEventSubscriber's trigger method.

Specified by:
subscribeToFeedUpdates in interface IAppboy
Parameters:
subscriber - A callback that should be executed when the news feed is updated.
See Also:

subscribeToFeedbackRequestEvents

public void subscribeToFeedbackRequestEvents(IEventSubscriber<SubmitFeedbackSucceeded> submitFeedbackSucceededSubscriber,
                                             IEventSubscriber<SubmitFeedbackFailed> submitFeedbackFailedSubscriber)
Description copied from interface: IAppboy
Subscribes to a events fired as a result of a IAppboy.submitFeedback(String, String, boolean) request. The submitFeedbackSucceededSubscriber callback will be called if the feedback has been successfully sent to and processed by Appboy. The submitFeedbackFailedSubscriber callback will be called if the feedback has been unsuccessfully processed by Appboy. The subscriber contains details of the error. Subscriptions should be cleaned up manually by calling IAppboy.removeSingleSubscription(com.appboy.events.IEventSubscriber, Class). All events are triggered from background threads and isolate any encountered exceptions. If you need to do work on the UI thread in response to an event, you will need to coordinate that in the IEventSubscriber's trigger method.

Specified by:
subscribeToFeedbackRequestEvents in interface IAppboy
Parameters:
submitFeedbackSucceededSubscriber - A callback that should be executed if the feedback has been successfully processed.
submitFeedbackFailedSubscriber - A callback that should be executed if Appboy could not process the feedback
See Also:
IAppboy.subscribeToFeedbackRequestEvents(com.appboy.events.IEventSubscriber, com.appboy.events.IEventSubscriber)

removeSingleSubscription

public <T> void removeSingleSubscription(IEventSubscriber<T> subscriber,
                                         java.lang.Class<T> eventClass)
Description copied from interface: IAppboy
Removes a single subscription associated with the given activity and event class. This should be called if you want to selectively unsubscribe from an event, but do not want to remove every subscription for the activity.

Specified by:
removeSingleSubscription in interface IAppboy
Parameters:
subscriber - The callback which is currently subscribed.
eventClass - The Event class which this IEventSubscriber is subscribed to.
See Also:
IAppboy.removeSingleSubscription(com.appboy.events.IEventSubscriber, Class)

changeUser

public AppboyUser changeUser(java.lang.String userId)
Description copied from interface: IAppboy
When you first start using Appboy on a device, the user is considered "anonymous". You can use this method to optionally identify a user with a unique ID, which enables the following: * If the same user is identified on another device, their user profile, usage history and event history will be shared across devices. * If your app is used by multiple people, you can assign each of them a unique identifier to track them separately. Only the most recent user on a particular device will receive push notifications and in-app messages. Note: Once you identify a user, you cannot go back to the "anonymous" profile. The transition from anonymous to identified tracking only happens once because the initial anonymous user receives special treatment to allow for preservation of their history. We recommend against changing the user id just because your app has entered a "logged out" state because it separates this device from the user profile and thus you will be unable to target the previously logged out user with re-engagement campaigns. If you anticipate multiple users on the same device, but only want to target one of them when your app is in a logged out state, we recommend separately keeping track of the user ID you want to target while logged out and switching back to that user ID as part of your app's logout process. If you identify a user which has never been identified on another device, the entire history of that user as an "anonymous" user on this device will be preserved and associated with the newly identified user. However, if you identify a user which *has* been identified in another app, the history of the anonymous user on this device will not be added to the existing profile for the identified user. When you request the user switch, the current session for the previous user is automatically sealed and a new session is started. Similarly, following a call to changeUser, any events which fire are guaranteed to be for the new user -- if a delayed or out of order server response provides a feedback response, message feed or slideup for the old user, no events will fire. If you change from one user to another, it is recommended that you explicitly request a feed and slideup refresh to provide fresh content for that new user (this is not required if you change from an anonymous user to a named user because the feed and slideup will stay the same). As part of the shutdown process for the old user, Appboy will start a background task which will attempt to flush all outstanding session/user/event data to the server. Upon completion of the background task, Appboy will clean up the storage, dispatch and event handling objects for the old user. If that background task fails, Appboy will not attempt to re-flush the old user's data until the next time that user logs in, instead preferring to quickly free up any resources being used by the old user's operations. When this method returns, all subsequent calls to your Appboy instance will operate on the new user, however, concurrent calls to other IAppboy methods are not in a forced order and thus could be on either the old or new user. For that reason, you should synchronize your calls to changeUser with other operations when in a multi-threaded environment.

Specified by:
changeUser in interface IAppboy
Parameters:
userId - An external user identifier
Returns:
the AppboyUser object representing the current active user after the change is complete.
See Also:
IAppboy.changeUser(String)

getCurrentUser

public AppboyUser getCurrentUser()
Description copied from interface: IAppboy
Returns the user currently being tracked by Appboy. Note that modifying values on instances of AppboyUser for a previous user will result in those values being stored locally, but they will not be synced with the Appboy server until that user becomes active again.

Specified by:
getCurrentUser in interface IAppboy
See Also:
IAppboy.getCurrentUser()

registerAppboyGcmMessages

public void registerAppboyGcmMessages(java.lang.String gcmRegistrationId)
Description copied from interface: IAppboy
Registers the device as eligible to receive push notifications from Appboy. Appboy will use the provided GCM registration ID to send the device GCM messages. This should only be used if you already use GCM messaging in your app from another provider. Otherwise, set the com.appboy.APPBOY_GCM_MESSAGING_REGISTRATION_ENABLED metadata attribute to "true" in the AndroidManifest.xml file to allow the Appboy SDK to handle the registration.

Specified by:
registerAppboyGcmMessages in interface IAppboy
Parameters:
gcmRegistrationId - The registration ID
See Also:
IAppboy.registerAppboyGcmMessages(String)

unregisterAppboyGcmMessages

public void unregisterAppboyGcmMessages()
Description copied from interface: IAppboy
Unregisters the device from receiving push notifications from Appboy.

Specified by:
unregisterAppboyGcmMessages in interface IAppboy
See Also:
IAppboy.unregisterAppboyGcmMessages()

fetchAndRenderImage

public void fetchAndRenderImage(java.lang.String imageUrl,
                                android.widget.ImageView imageView)
Description copied from interface: IAppboy
Asynchronously fetches the image at imageUrl and renders it in imageView if imageView is still attached to that same URL when the image is available. Uses LRU memory and disc caching to minimize network traffic.

Specified by:
fetchAndRenderImage in interface IAppboy
Parameters:
imageUrl - - The URL to the image resource.
imageView - - The ImageView to render the image in once it is downloaded or retrieved from cache.
See Also:
IAppboy.fetchAndRenderImage(String, android.widget.ImageView)
